results.title: Come September
results.creator_credit: Robert Rothols and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This film was made during the Centenary Royal Show in 1972, to commemorate 100 years of traditional partnership between the Department of Agriculture and the Royal Agriculture Society in the Royal Show. Using locations sound and music only, the film aims to give an impression of the contrasting facets of the Melbourne Show, and how it sets out to attract a wide range of people, mainly from urban areas.

results.title: Come see the dolphins
results.creator_credit: Tom Ascher and Coronet Instructional Media
results.brief_description: Presents the story of a young boy who accompanies his father, a dolphin keeper, to the zoo to see the dolphins. The boy learns of the appearance of dolphins, what they eat and how they communicate and navigate. Skillful photography includes observations underwater and behind the scenes views of equipment and workers needed to maintain the dolphin pool.

results.title: Come out fighting
results.brief_description: Low budget realistic work made with assistance from the Experimental Film and Television Fund. Adapted from a play by Harry Martin, it presents a crisis in the life of an Aboriginal boxer in the face of conflicting demands from Aboriginal friends, fight promoters and students campaigning for Aboriginal rights. Cast includes Michael Karpaney, Cliff Neale, Bethany Lee, Peter Green, Bob Horsfall, Peter Adams, Brian Torrens.

results.title: Come out fighting
results.brief_description: A young Aboriginal boxer is taken up by University students and finds it hard to adjust entering their bourgeois white world. This short is ragged and rough around the edges but it offers a rivetting glimpse into black and white relations in the early seventies, as well as some wonderful realistic sequences set in inner-city boxing gyms.

results.title: Come on Bushy
results.creator_credit: Bill Bush, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Bill Bush joined the army for a bit of adventure and to escape troubles at home. He fought in Korea, where his skills as a paramedic were also utilised. He continued this work into civilian life. With a mantra of doing what you were told, without complaint, Bill ultimately leads a happy life doing what he loves.

results.title: Come into my parlour, said the spider to the fly
results.creator_credit: Densey Clyne, Jim Frazier and Mantis Wildlife Films
results.brief_description: Deals with the predatory techniques of the Australian spiders that feed on insects. Includes spiders that build lidded burrows, spin webs, stack their prey, cast nets, or lure moths into a whirling line.

results.title: Come in spinner
results.creator_credit: Robert Marchand, Jan Chapman and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: It is October 1944, and the Pacific War has brought American forces to Sydney, turning it into a gaudy garrison town. The gamblers and good time charlies converge on the South Pacific Hotel, Sydney’s finest. Amidst the social upheavals of war, a society is in flux, marriages are strained, values are tested. The heart of the South Pacific Hotel is the beauty salon run by three remarkable women. This is the story of one week in their lives. Based on the novel by Dymphna Cusack and Florence James.

results.title: Come and see = Idi i smotri
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Highly acclaimed Russian feature about a young boy, living in occupied territory, who joins the partisans to fight against the Nazis. An expressionistic work of great beauty that depicts abject horror, the narrative, based on true events, is framed as a coming-of-age story. The protagonist, a survivor through chance, is forced to repeatedly witness the awfulness of genocide, rape, destruction and evil, robbing him of youth, innocence and trust. Unforgettably poetic scenes reflect the brutality of victory, magnified through the eyes of a child. Adapted from the book by Ales Adamovich.
